sentences.sentence: In the morning he got up, and ate some fruit from the trees.
He began to make his way through the great forest, crying bitterly( 伤心地 ).
And he asked every creature( 动物 ) he met if perhaps they had seen his mother.
He said to the Mole( 鼹鼠 ), “You can go under the ground.
Tell me, is my mother there?”
And the Mole( 鼹鼠 ) answered, “You have blinded my eyes. How should I know?”
He said to the Snow Bird, “You can fly over the tops of the tall trees, and can see the whole world.
Tell me, can you see my mother?”
And the Snow Bird answered, “You have cut off( 切断 ) my wings for your pleasure. How should I fly?”
And to the little Squirrel( 松鼠 ) who lived in the tree, and was lonely, he said, “Where is my mother?”
And the Squirrel( 松鼠 ) answered, “You have killed mine.
Do you plan to kill your own mother as well?”
The Star-Child cried, bowed( 低下 ) his head, and prayed( 祈求 ) for forgiveness( 原谅 ) from God.
Then he went on through the forest, looking for the beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ).
On the third day he came to the other side of the forest and went down into the valley( 山谷 ).
When he passed through the villages the children laughed at him, and threw stones at him because he was so ugly.
All the people in the villages chased( 驱逐 ) him away, and no one had any pity on him.
He asked everyone he could if they had seen the beggar( 乞丐 )-woman who was his mother, but nobody had seen her.
He wandered( 流浪 ) over the whole world for three years, and often seemed to see his mother on the road in front of him.
He would call to her, and run after her until the rough( 崎岖的 ) road made his feet bleed, but he could not catch up with( 追赶上 ) her.
The people he met along the way said they had not seen her, or anyone like her, and they laughed at his sorrow( 悲伤 ).
For three years he wandered( 流浪 ) over the whole world, and in the world he found people had neither love nor kindness for him.
But this was the world which he had helped to make, back when he was once very proud.
One evening he came to the gate of a walled city that was by a river.
Even though he was tired, he tried to enter.
But the soldiers( 士兵 ) who were guarding the city put their spears( 长矛 ) across the gate, and said to him roughly( 粗暴地 ), “Why do you want to enter the city?”
“I am looking for my mother,” he answered.
“I beg( 乞求 ) you to let me pass, because she may be in this city.”
But they  laughed at( 嘲笑 ) him, and one soldier( 士兵 ) who had a black beard( 胡须 ) said,
“Your mother will not be happy when she sees you, because you are uglier than a toad( 癞蛤蟆 ), and more disgusting( 令人厌恶的 ) than a snake.
Get away from here. Your mother does not live in this city.”
Another soldier( 士兵 ), who carried a yellow flag, said to him,
“Who is your mother, and why are you looking for her?”
And he answered, “My mother is a beggar( 乞丐 ) like me, and I have treated her cruelly( 残酷地 ).
I beg( 乞求 ) you to let me pass so that she may give me her forgiveness( 原谅 ), if she is in this city.”
But they would not let him enter, and they chased( 驱赶 ) him away with their spears( 长矛 ).
As he turned away crying, a third soldier( 士兵 ) came toward the gate.
His armor( 盔甲 ) was covered with silver flowers, and he carried a shield( 盾牌 ) that shone like a mirror( 镜子 ).
He came up to the other soldiers( 士兵 ), and asked them who had been trying to enter the city.
And they said to him, “It is a beggar( 乞丐 )-child, and we have chased( 驱赶 ) him away.”
“No,” he said, laughing, “we will sell the ugly thing as a slave( 奴隶 ), and his price will be the cost of a bowl of sweet wine.”
An old and cruel-looking( 面相凶残的 ) man who was passing by( 经过 ) called out, and said, “I will buy him for that price.”
When he had paid the price, he took the Star-Child by the hand and led him into the city.
They went through many streets, until they came to a little door set in a wall.
The old man touched the door with the ring on his finger, and it opened.
They entered, and went down five metal( 金属 ) steps into a garden filled with black flowers and green jars( 瓦罐 ).
Then the old man took a silk ribbon( 绸带 ) out of his pocket, and tied it over the eyes of the Star-Child, and pushed him forward.
When the ribbon( 绸带 ) was taken off his eyes, the Star-Child found himself in a dark prison( 牢笼 ).
There was no window, because it was deep under the ground, and the only light was from a small lantern( 灯笼 ).
The old man set before him some hard bread on a plate( 盘子 ) and said, “Eat.”
Then he put some dirty water in a cup and said, “Drink.”
When the Star-Child had eaten the bread and drunk the water, the old man went out, and locked the door behind him.

question.cn: 为什么鼹鼠对女乞丐的去向一无所知？
question.en: Why did the Mole know nothing about the beggar-woman?

options.cn: 因为他的眼睛被星孩弄瞎了。
options.en: Because his eyes were blinded by the Star-Child.

options.cn: 因为鼹鼠的腿被星孩弄断了。
options.en: Because the Mole's legs were cut off by the Star-Child.
